title: 5 restaurants we can’t wait to try in February
author: Jillian Dara
bullets: Ama at The Atlas in Allston features global comfort cuisine inspired by Nepali roots with a focus on sustainability.
Boxfish in Watertown offers an ocean-to-table menu emphasizing seafood, including brown butter lobster toast and Blue fin tuna tacos.
Swingers in Back Bay combines indoor mini golf, multiple bars, and New York-style pizza, opening February 20.

title: Panera to close bakery facility in Franklin, lay off nearly 100 workers
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Panera will close its Franklin bakery, laying off 92 workers as part of a shift to a par-baked goods model.
The Franklin facility at 290 Beaver St. will cease operations by the end of March, part of the Panera Rise strategy.
Panera is offering severance packages and job assistance to affected employees amid its transition to serving fresh bread all day.

title: 16-year-old New Zealander ran a 3:48 mile at BU’s Terrier Classic, set a junior world record
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Sam Ruthe, 16, set a junior world record with a 3:48.88 mile at BU's Terrier Classic.
Ruthe broke both the under-18 world record and New Zealand's national mile record, surpassing John Walker's 1982 mark.
Ruthe's accomplishment makes him the youngest athlete to have run a mile under four minutes at 15 years old.

title: Watch: Ms. G, Massachusetts’ official groundhog, issues annual prediction
author: Heather Alterisio
bullets: Ms. G, Massachusetts' official groundhog, predicted six more weeks of winter at Drumlin Farm Wildlife Sanctuary in Lincoln.
Roughly 50 people attended Ms. G's prediction event, despite the 16-degree weather causing delay in her appearance.
Ms. G was designated the state’s official groundhog in 2014 after a successful campaign by students and wildlife advocates.

title: Massachusetts keeps losing residents to other states, Census finds
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Massachusetts experienced a net outflow of over 30,000 residents to other states, posing risks to the workforce and economy.
Top destinations for departing Massachusetts residents include Florida, New Hampshire, New York, California, Connecticut, and Rhode Island.
Although international immigration contributes to population growth, its slowing rate may impact the economy as domestic out-migration continues.

title: Photos: Day 2 at Something in the Way fest at Roadrunner
author: Boston.com Staff
bullets: Twelve bands performed on day two of the 'Something in the Way fest' at Roadrunner in Brighton.
The event concluded with a headlining act by Seattle-based alt rock band Sunny Day Real Estate.
Photographer Ben Stas captured performances by Wicca Phase Springs Eternal, Park National, and more.

title: For Bourne, the new Sagamore Bridge takings echo a long past
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Massachusetts will acquire and demolish 13 homes in Bourne for the new Sagamore Bridge project.
Residents have experienced multiple eminent domain projects since the early 1900s, including Cape Cod Canal construction.
Affected families, like Phillip Michaud's, face relocation, challenging the strong neighborhood ties established over decades.

title: ‘It’s a joke’: David Pastrnak, Bruins vent after controversial OT call in Stadium Series
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: David Pastrnak's overtime goal was disallowed and he received a penalty, leading to Bruins' 6-5 shootout loss to Tampa.
Officials called a slash on Pastrnak in OT, giving Lightning a power play despite Boston's possession of the puck.
Bruins lamented inconsistent officiating while acknowledging their own errors, blowing a 5-1 lead with multiple penalties.

title: Active-duty Boston police officer dies after more than 30 years with department, BPD says
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Officer Scott MacIsaac of Boston Police died of cancer after 30 years of service, starting in 1995.
MacIsaac, a U.S. Army veteran, was assigned to West Roxbury and previously worked in multiple districts.
MacIsaac was commended for his role in the Boston Marathon bombings and lifesaving efforts during his career.

title: Suspect charged with murder after mother and son shot to death in Fall River
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Arlington Cole, 54, charged with two counts of murder and unlawful firearm possession in Fall River shooting.
Victims Elizabeth Almeida, 54, and her son Nicholas Almeida, 25, were fatally shot on Barnes Street.
Cole, reportedly in a relationship with Elizabeth Almeida, to be arraigned Monday, according to prosecutors.
